content: The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" emphasizes the importance of preventive medicine in reducing healthcare costs and improving public health. It highlights the need for more public health professionals and increased focus on preventive methods to address chronic conditions. The Act also aims to provide loan payment assistance for preventive medicine physicians to strengthen the preventive medicine workforce. The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" promotes preventive medicine to reduce healthcare costs and improve public health. It offers up to $20,000 in loan payment assistance for eligible preventive medicine physicians who receive board certification between fiscal years 2008-2012. Eligible physicians must apply to the Secretary of Health and Human Services with required information. The term "school of medicine" and "Secretary" are defined in the Public Health Service Act. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008-2012 to carry out the Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007. SEC. 4. WELLNESS PROGRAM EMPLOYER CREDIT. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section for a wellness program employer credit. The wellness program employer credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows eligible employers to receive a credit of 25% of expenses incurred to develop and implement a qualified wellness program. The credit is capped at $200 per qualified employee, and eligible employers must keep accurate records of employee participation in preventive services and programs. The qualified wellness program for eligible employers includes health risk assessments, preventive services, counseling sessions, and seminars on smoking, obesity, stress management, and physical fitness. The eligible employer's qualified wellness program covers various health topics such as smoking, obesity, stress management, physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health. Qualified employees must participate in the program, with at least 50% of full-time employees included. The eligible employer's qualified wellness program requires qualified participants to engage in annual preventive services or programs, including a health risk assessment. The program will not apply after December 31, 2012. Conforming amendments include a wellness program employer credit under section 45O(a) of the Code. The wellness program employer credit under section 45O(a) is amended in the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The wellness program participant credit, section 25E, applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The wellness program participant credit allows a $200 tax credit for qualified employees who participate in a qualified wellness program. Qualified employees are full-time employees who participate in at least 2 annual preventive services and undergo a health risk assessment. The eligible employer must develop and implement a qualified wellness program during the taxable year. The program includes health risk assessments, offering at least 2 preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, and providing counseling sessions and seminars on topics like smoking. The eligible employer must offer annual counseling sessions and seminars on various health topics, with at least 50% of full-time employees participating. The eligible employer must offer counseling sessions and seminars on health topics, with employees participating, and keep accurate records. This section does not apply after December 31, 2012. The amendment regarding the Wellness program participant credit applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007.
